titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0948, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

msHeading.title: Lectionary
msHeading.otherName: Saint Menas the Wonder Worker Lectionary

overview.p: Gospel lectionary in Greek. Synaxarion with ecphonetic notation. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 46.

headpieces.p: Headpieces of scrollwork and geometric patterns in red, and red and black (fols. 33v, 54r).

initials.p: Major initials in red (30-35 mm) set off from text and embellished with foliate and bead motifs.

physDesc.extent: 109 leaves, of which 2 are raised pastedowns of paper, and 1 is a paper leaf containing a description of the manuscript's history.

foliation.p: 1 (unfoliated paper pastedown) + 1 (unfoliated paper leaf) + 106 + 1 (unfoliated paper pastedown). Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-106.

collation.p: 15 quires extant, each of 8 leaves with the exception of quire 14 of 6 leaves. Estimate of content lost: leaves 1-3 of quire 1 (before fol. 1); leaves 8-11 of quire 2 (after fol. 7, John 6:14-27, Saturday, Week 2 of Easter. Ends with 6:22 at αλλα μονοι οι μαθη[ται], and begins on fol. 8r with John 5:1-15, 4th Sunday of Easter, with 5:3 at, [ασθε]νουντων τυφλων χωλων ξηρων); unknown number of leaves (after fol. 106). It is assumed the text of the missing leaves would have contained the remainder of the Twelve Lections of the Holy Passions, Heothina lections, and a Menologion.
Quire number present on quire 15 (ιε) only (fol. 104r, upper margin).

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 190 x 140 mm (fol. 18r). Each column is 190 x 60 mm with a space of 20 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 25 to 32 lines. Ruling with hard point. Pricking in the outer margins.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in dark brown ink.
Punctuation includes middle, double, and triple points, and marks of elision. Quotation marks in left margin next to each line of quoted text.
Corrections to the text include erasure and additions in the margins noted with reference marks.

condition.p: A number of leaves loose. Typed description of the manuscript's history hinged to margin of broken front leaf. Some insect damage to parchment, paper, wooden boards, and linen cloth. Paint and gesso of the icon on the front board damaged. Loss of back covering, possibly an icon of the Resurrection, leaving exposed cloth. Sewing visible through a missing section of linen over the spine.

binding.p: Bound in board wrapped in linen.

decoNote.p: Front cover: Icon of The Crucifixion of Christ with the Virgin Mary and the Evangelist John at the foot of the cross.

origin.p: The manuscript is judged to have been written on the island of Cyprus in either the late 12th or early 13th century.

provenance.p: Belonged at one time to the Monastery of Saint Menas the Wonder Worker near Lárnaka, Cyprus (undated, front pastedown, recto). An additional inscription recorded in 1868 notes that the manuscript was from the Convent of Queen Catherine on Cyprus's Mount Olympus, and in that year was presented to Lieutenant Colonel Shervinton by Demetrios Pierides, a Cypriot bank director and antiquarian.
Gifts to the monastery and the death of Mathew, one of its abbots are documented among other undated colophons and notes (front and back inside covers and rectos of raised pastedowns).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago from Maggs Bros. (London) in 1941 with funds provided by the Divinity School Library and Friends of the Library.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

msHeading.title: Lectionary
msHeading.otherName: Saint Menas the Wonder Worker Lectionary

overview.p: Gospel lectionary in Greek. Synaxarion with ecphonetic notation. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 46.

msItem.summary: Synaxarion. John, Weekday, Saturday, and Sunday Lections.
msItem.note: Begins with John 1:35-51, Wednesday, Week 1 of Easter, at 1:42, αυτω ο ιησους ειπεν.

msItem.summary: Synaxarion. Matthew, Weekday, Saturday, and Sunday Lections.
Synaxarion. Luke, Saturday, and Sunday Lections.
Synaxarion. Great Lent, Saturday and Sunday Lections.
Synaxarion. Holy Week, Monday through Thursday Lections.
Synaxarion. Twelve Lections of the Holy Passions (lacking).
msItem.note: 1st lection, John 13:31-18:1, end with 17:15 at, αυτους εκ του πο[νηρου].
